keyTakeAways: Afghanistan and Pakistan have agreed to an immediate ceasefire after more than a week of deadly cross-border fighting.
The conflict, considered the deadliest in several years, involves accusations of cross-border terrorism and violations of sovereignty.
The Pakistani Air Force conducted airstrikes in Afghanistan’s Paktika province, killing dozens of militants and at least 10 civilians, including three local cricketers.
Afghan officials and the Taliban condemned the attacks, accusing Pakistan of violating Afghan sovereignty and engaging in deliberate aggression.
The national cricket board of Afghanistan has boycotted an upcoming series in Pakistan following the deaths of young players.
The International Cricket Council expressed sorrow over the deaths of three promising Afghan cricketers.
Qatar and Turkey acted as mediators to facilitate the ceasefire negotiations.
The Durand Line, the 2,611-kilometer border between the two nations, remains a source of contention as Afghanistan has never officially recognized it.
The core issue remains unresolved: the Taliban's denial of responsibility for cross-border militant activity and Pakistan’s insistence on targeting militant groups like Hafiz Gul Bahadur.
Experts warn that without sustained diplomatic efforts, the conflict could resurface, threatening regional stability and the resurgence of extremist groups like ISIS and al-Qaeda.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Afghanistan and Pakistan have agreed to an immediate ceasefire after more than a week of deadly cross-border fighting, mediated by Qatar and Turkey. The conflict, rooted in accusations of cross-border terrorism and violations of sovereignty, escalated when Pakistan conducted airstrikes in Afghanistan’s Paktika province targeting militant groups like Hafiz Gul Bahadur. The strikes killed at least 10 civilians, including three local cricketers, prompting widespread condemnation, a cricket boycott by Afghanistan’s national board, and international outcry from the ICC. The Taliban accused Pakistan of violating Afghan sovereignty, while Pakistan’s army chief urged mutual security. Despite the ceasefire, experts warn that the core issue—Taliban denial of responsibility for militant activity and the disputed Durand Line—remains unresolved, threatening long-term regional instability.
title: Afghanistan and Pakistan Agree to Ceasefire Amid Deadly Border Conflict
